subject: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)
msgSnippet: I am curious as to why terminal unstressed -ior is spelt with letters #26+#36+#25 & terminal -ion (with y-sound) is spelt with letters #17+#36+#23. The
messageBody:
I am curious as to why terminal unstressed -ior is spelt with letters
#26+#36+#25 & terminal -ion (with y-sound) is spelt with letters
#17+#36+#23. The examples "senior" & "junior" used in the Quikscript
manual for unstressed terminal -ior have significant "y" sounds in
them & this is indicated in the dictionary pronunciation key as well.
Is this simply a case of British - American difference? The example
"furrier" seems to be where the spelling of terminal unstressed -ior
(#26+#36+#25) is being aimed at, even though that clearly does not
have the "y" sound that "senior" & "junior" have.

So, would this be an acceptable alteration of the rule?

Terminal unstressed -ior (with Y-sound) ... #17+#36+#25

Examples : senior, junior, behavior

If this issue has been brought up previously, I apologize for bringing
it up again. I could not find this issue in previous messages. Thank
you.

I am curious as to why terminal unstressed -ior is spelt with letters
#26+#36+#25 & terminal -ion (with y-sound) is spelt with letters
#17+#36+#23. The examples "senior" & "junior" used in the Quikscript
manual for unstressed terminal -ior have significant "y" sounds in
them & this is indicated in the dictionary pronunciation key as well.
Is this simply a case of British - American difference? The example
"furrier" seems to be where the spelling of terminal unstressed -ior
(#26+#36+#25) is being aimed at, even though that clearly does not
have the "y" sound that "senior" & "junior" have.

So, would this be an acceptable alteration of the rule?

Terminal unstressed -ior (with Y-sound) ... #17+#36+#25

Examples : senior, junior, behavior

If this issue has been brought up previously, I apologize for bringing
it up again. I could not find this issue in previous messages. Thank
you.
